review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198184866498', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1674474196}
review:
[h1] das wohl schlechteste Spiel, das ich je gestartet hab[/h1]

dabei hätte es wirklich besser sein können. Oracle ist ein Spiel, das ich nur besitze, da es aus einer Zeit meines Lebens kam, in der ich dachte, dass Walking Simulatoren wirklich ein interessantes Nischen-Genre ist. Oracle treibt es auf die Spitze, weil es eine extrem langsame Bewegungsgeschwindigkeit mit einer nicht gerade kleinen Welt kombiniert, was ne unfassbar schlechte Idee ist bei nem Walking Simulator. 

Man könnte dann meinen, man soll halt die Landschaft auf sich wirken lassen, aber das ist halt kaum möglich, wenn:

a) Die Berglandschaft maximal okay aussieht, eigentlich verdeckte Objekte durch unsichtbaren Boden zu sehen sind oder hier und da random ne Blume in der Luft schwebt

b) das Soundsystem aus einem monotonen tripp trapp der Schritte besteht, das sich niemals ändert. Man hat auch einfach keinen Grund, mal anzuhalten, weil man eh kaum vorankommt, was dazu führt, dass man ein konstantes Fußtreten als audio hat. kann man es ändern? nein, es gibt keine Audiooption, bis auf die Sprache der Übersetzung (auf die komm ich noch zu sprechen)

c) einem das Gefühl von Erkunden vermittelt werden soll, wenn dann an interessant aussehenden Orten überall unsichtbare Wände inkonstant gezogen werden. Das kann man also auch vergessen.

Oracle will eigentlich eine recht komplexe Geschichte erzählen, tut es aber extrem ungeschickt, indem - von Orten abhängige - Soundpakete bei Betreten ausgelöst werden, die dann nicht unbedingt in der richtigen Reihenfolge ablaufen, weil man auch mal vom Weg abkommen kann. Der Sprecher ist auch furchtbar eintönig und hatte wahrscheinlich von allen am wenigsten Bock auf diesen Mist. Mich kann auch keiner davon überzeugen, dass die für die Übersetzungen nicht einfach mal kurzerhand Google Übersetzer angeschmissen haben (das klappt vielleicht heute, weil der echt besser geworden ist, aber eben nicht 2017). 

am meißten Spaß machen am Ende die Gedankenspiele, mit welchen Formulierungen man dieses Spiel zerreißen kann, nachdem man endlich die 12/24 Errungenschaft geholt hat, damit das Spiel zumindest Steam-komplettiert wird. aber mal ernsthaft, ich weiß, das Spiel kostet nichtmal nen Euro, aber was noch viel kostbarer ist, das ist eure Zeit und die ist nichtmal eine einzige Sekunde dieser Katastrophe wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1653419993}
review:
"Oracle" ist ein First-Person-Walking Simulator.

Wir finden uns auf einer hügeligen Insel wieder, die wir erkunden sollen. Kommen wir zu bestimmten Orten - wie einer Kapelle oder einer Brücke - wird uns ein kurzer Text eingeblendete und vorgelesen.

Und mehr gibt es auch nicht zu tun. "Oracle" ist wirklich ein Walking Simulator, aber leider einer, der alle Klischees des Genres bestätigt.

Die Laufgeschwindigkeit, oder besser: Gehgeschwindigkeit ist belastend langsam. Das Drücken der Shift-Taste führt nur zu einem anderen Geräusch, nicht zu einer merklichen Beschleunigung. Und die einzelnen Orte liegen weit auseinander. Entdeckt man einen Ort in der Ferne, den man vergessen hat, kann man sich auf mindestens fünf Minuten ereignisloses Gelatsche einstellen. 

Das wäre nicht so schlimm, wenn wenigstens die Welt oder die Geschichte interessant wären. Aber nichts davon. 

Bei der "Geschichte" handelt es sich um kurze Interview-Antworten eines Typen, der sich auf eine einsame Insel zurückgezogen hat und gefühlt gewissen Substanzen nicht abgeneigt ist. Stilistisch und inhaltlich sind die Antworten belanglos und ungelenk. Es klingt wie ein unsympathischer Hipster, der meint, sich nach einem Leben in New York finden zu müssen. Das will man nicht wissen. Zudem wirkt alles wie reine Behauptung. Immerhin macht der englischsprachige Sprecher einen soliden Job. 

Gefühlt hat das Gesagte überhaupt nichts mit der verlassen wirkenden Inselwelt zu tun. Und auch wenn es Anknüpfungspunkte gibt, sind die doch so ungelenk und talentbefreit konstruiert, daß man beschämt wegschauen mag. 

Die Inselwelt ist auch nicht gerade gut gebaut. Auch wenn sie an einigen Stellen für ein Indie-Game zumindest passabel ausschaut, fallen doch zahlreiche Fehler und Unzulänglichkeiten auf. Schwebende Steine, unvollständig platzierte Felsen, unsichtbare Wände und große Objekte, durch die man einfach durchlaufen kann wie durch Luft. Das alles wirkt unfertig und unsauber. 

Die ständig laufende Klaviermusik, die als "brilliant soundtrack" angepriesen wird, klingt wie das lustlose rumimprovisieren eines gelangweilten Pianisten. 

"Oracle" sieht auf den ersten Blick interessant aus, ist aber einfach nur ein schlecht programmiertes Latsch-Spiel mit unangenehm  prätentiös erzählter Geschichte. 

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
6/10 Atmosphäre
3/10 Story
5/10 Grafik
4/10 Sound
5/10 Spielmechanik
3/10 Balancing
5/10 Spielspass 

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Ausgelatscht.

[h1][b]5/10 Gesamtwertung

review:
This is the most pretentious game I've ever played. (And I've played quite a few artsy games!)

I can certainly enjoy philosophical meanderings, uses of similes and metaphors, etc. But it has to be actually intelligent and well written! And the monologue in this game just isn't.

Note how the game calls its own story for "awesome" on the Steam Store page. It really, REALLY isn't. Also, how the game starts with telling you through a monologue how important the protagonist is. It all just really feels like an author self insert, trying to show how intelligent they (think they) are.

So, the story is actually just pretty crap. This game is basically trying to copy Dear Esther with its writing(and has the same basica "walking sim" gameplay), but it really fails miserably. Play Dear Esther instead, or even some of Tonguc Bodur's okay titles, instead of this.

Oh yeah, the developer didn't even manage to put in some simple swimming physics, so you can just walk around on the bottom of the lake. And you can climb up nearly 90 degree walls by jumping.

Also, the voice acting isn't good. It's not the worst I've encountered, but it certainly isn't good.

Oh, "over 30 locations to explore", the store description says! Not really! Just a singular location, but with more than 30 landmarks to discover.

Ugh, this is just a terrible game all around. It doesn't even look that great. Lots of *much* better walking sims out there! I actually wanted to give this game a chance, despite the other negative reviews. I've found some half decent games that way before. But this just isn't one of those times. Steer clear of this one!

review:
这是个步行模拟器，首先游戏机制极为单调，缺乏创新和挑战性。解谜元素大多是重复的模式，玩家需要不断寻找线索、解开谜题，但这些谜题设计过于简单和线性，让整个游戏过程显得枯燥乏味。缺乏新颖的游戏机制和有趣的挑战，让玩家很快失去了对游戏的兴趣。

其次游戏的心理恐怖元素并没有达到预期的效果。游戏试图营造紧张恐怖的氛围，但却显得过于刻意和生硬。恐怖场景的设置缺乏真实感，缺乏恐怖氛围的建立，让玩家很难真正感受到恐怖的氛围，反而更多地感到无聊和厌倦。

总的来说，Oracle是一款空洞无趣的虚假承诺，游戏机制单调、恐怖元素不足、故事情节混乱，让玩家很难被吸引和投入到游戏中。我建议对寻求真正恐怖体验和引人入胜剧情的玩家慎重考虑，避免浪费时间和金钱在这款虚假的游戏上。

review:
[h3]Oracle[/h3]
[u]Laufsimulator[/u]

Beim Durchstreifen einer Insel sind einige Orte zu finden, um das Spiel erfolgreich zu beenden - das Ende kommt dann auch ganz abrupt - was eigentlich auch egal ist, da die Erzählungen über Magie, eine Frau, ein Interview und andere Dinge in der Reihenfolge erzählt werden, in der Du die Örtlichkeiten findest - unabhängig davon, ob es eine Geschichte ergibt oder nicht. 

Was mir gefiel war die gemütliche Erkundung der Insel und die recht ansprechende Grafik, auch wenn es kein wirklicher Hingucker ist. Manche Einfälle bezüglich der Orte waren ganz witzig, Interaktionen waren nicht möglich, aber auch nicht nötig. 
Auch die Begleitmusik war ok, das Klavier klang so nach 90er Jahre US-Großstadtspielfilm - schwer zu beschreiben, aber ich empfand es als Mittel zwischen melodiösem Geklimpere und Jazz, weswegen ich sie leiser stellen musste, aber genervt hat sie mich dennoch keineswegs. Die Geschmäcker sind halt verschieden.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2535979835
Weniger gut waren vereinzelt Grafikfehler wie floating oder nicht ausgefüllte Texturen. An manchen Stellen hing ich fest und musste das Spiel beenden um es dann an einem vorherigen Punkt fortzusetzen. Es gibt auch keine eigentliche Geschichte, es sei denn man findet die Orte in einer zufällig sinnvollen Reihenfolge. 
Audio des Sprechers ist englisch, die deutschen Textübersetzungen sind vermutlich mit einer mangelhaften Software gemacht worden, daher versteht man kaum, worum es geht - fürchterlicher geht es nicht.

Für die Beendigung brauchte ich etwas mehr als 2 Stunden. Dann hatte ich auch die ganze Insel gesehen und war froh, dass ich fertig war. Errungenschaften hin oder her, es hat mich leider nicht gefesselt.

Fazit: Als Laufsimulator hätte es durchaus besser sein können, aber so wie es sich beim Spielen angefühlt hat, kann ich es nicht empfehlen.

review:
I'm just going to get right to the point: This game feels unfinished and in it's current state I can't recommend it. 

The Bad: 
1.) The textures are literally painful if you're prone to migraines or motion sickness from first person/low texture games. I felt sick to my stomach after about ten minutes but soldiered on in hopes of something worthwhile appearing. There's tons of pop-ins, glowing trees, floating flowers, and the distant textures are plain awful. There's a lot of repetition regarding structures while the more unique ones lack any reason for existing within the story. 

2.) The overall sound design is poorly implemented. There's incessant, clomping footsteps regardless of the terrain and the jump sound is a very strange whomp sound for lack of better terminology.  The narration also sounds like it was recorded in a tin can filled with static. The music is lovely though. The narrator is also pretty good in general. 

3.) The story bits are shades of interesting but overall it's basically rambling lacking in cohesion almost like it's a first draft. I imagine it would be be quite good if it had been edited and sorted into some sort of overarching narrative. 

Say Something Nice: 
I can tell that the story being told matters to the dev. I'm interested in what they're saying but currently it's just not cohesive enough for me to understand the overall intent being put forth. I think that working on this some more would be beneficial and I think it'd be worthwhile because you do have an interesting premise. Unfortunately, the execution leaves a lot to be desired currently.

Edit: I also don't have access to achievements on my end. I have no idea if this is a Steam thing or if the game just doesn't offer them anymore. I figured I'd give a head's up to anyone looking to achievement hunt though.

review:
[b][i]”Oracle[/i] is a single player, open world experience with dozens of locations ready to be explored with a great story ready to be unraveled. Discover the secrets of the Island and find out the truth about Quijana and what's happening around the world, why you are alone, living on an island, hiding from your past.”
[/b]

[b]Good:[/b]
- Large Area to explore
- Easy achievements
- Good voice acting
- Great soundtrack
- Cheap

[b]Bad:[/b]
- Terrible voice acting
- Graphics are clunky
- Glitchy Terrain
- Kinda boring
- No obvious structure of story
- Leaves you unfulfilled
- Very short


 [b]Ratings:[/b] (Terrible) (Very Bad) (Bad) (Okay) (Good) (Very Good) (Amazing)

[b]Graphics - [i]Bad[/i][/b] - (The graphics are not great. The gorgeous scenery and map almost makes up for the poor textures but honestly it will hurt your eyes after a while.)
[b]Soundtrack/Dialogue - [iOkay[/i][/b] - (The voice acting is nice, even when you have no idea what they are talking about. The jumping sound began to really grind after a while as it completely broke any sense of immersion.The soundtrack is nice and calming.)
[b]Atmosphere - [i]Bad[/i][/b] - (This is a hard one as the atmosphere at times could be considered good. However, the glitches in the terrain, awkward graphics and strange storyline really made it hard to be enveloped by the game.)
[b]Controls - [i]Okay[/i][/b] - (Controls themselves are okay but occasionally got stuck in places..)
[b]Difficulty - [i]N/A[/i][/b] - (Not going to grade as it's a walking simulator.)
[b]Replay Value - [i]Bad[/i][/b] - (No real replay value)

[b]Overall Gameplay: [i]Bad[/i][/b] 
[b]Worth - [i]£0.15[/i][/b] - (Buy on Sale if you wanna kill half an hour)

[b]Overall Rating:[/b][i]Oracle[/i] is a game I wish I enjoyed. It's a clunky and unfinished version of Dear Esther. The game's story could be interesting but there's just so many answered questions and no understanding of the actual gameplay, it's impossible to follow. The graphics look like they were drawn by a child and even some areas have poorly copy/pasted structures. The overall design of the map is gorgeous, but still not worth the time honestly. Although its cheap, look elsewhere for a decent walking simulator.

review:
Oracle je walking simulator. To aby bylo jasno hned na začátek. Ale třeba z mého pohledu to není u her jen na škodu. Nebo ne vždycky. 
U Oracle je to však opravdu jen o tom průchodu mapou, koukání po zajímavých bodech, dokud nevyzobete všechny a hra nekončí. Na poprvé není špatné, ale větší motivace ke hraní moc není. 
Vizuál je na první pohled líbivý, ale po projití na jiná místa to začne kapku pokulhávat, a jakmile objevíte některé nedosedlé předměty, levitující zdi a kameny, tak to také nepřidá. 
Závěrem snad jen dodám, že hra by měla odrážet denní dobu. Jde o zajímavou věc, kterou ještě musím vyzkoušet, tak uvidíme, ale za to alespoň půl bodíku navrch.
Suma sumárum nejde o špatnou "hru" a za cenu, za kterou je nabízena, určitě za vykoušení stojí. Na druhou stranu se však v žánru walking simulátorů dá najít spousta lepších titulů, a tak - 5,5/10

Turns out you sink like a stone, and the river is so deep I had to walk along the bottom of it until I reached the ocean so that I could walk up onto the island again. Also when you jump sometimes you go straight through things...like the ground.

Also the island is huge, you have no direction for where you should be going, and you move very slowly with nothing but music to accompany you for large chunks of this. If the story was good it might redeem it, but I'm halfway through the achievements and I still have no idea what this dude is going on about. It feels like I'm listening to a personal letter written to the narrator's friend. He talks about people and events that I have no reference point for. 

On a whole, weird and I found it wasn't really worth the time I put in.

review:
[h1]Очередная бродилка и очередная халутрная работа.[/h1]

[i]От себя лишь скажу, что я ничего не имею против бродилок - это своего рода релакс-жанр в игровой индустрии. А для хорошей бродилки достаточно большой локации, пейзажей, музыки и хорошей истории.[/i]

И так плюсы:
1) Остров с хорошими пейзажами.
2) Музыка, хоть и ввиде одной короткой звуковой дорожки пущенной по кругу, но чем-то все равно цепляет.
3) Иногда попадаются интересные локации.

Минусы:
1) Плохая оптимизация.
2) Попадаются багованные текстуры от чего: застреваем, проходим насквозь, упираемся.
3) Отсутствует физика, поленились даже подъем по лестнице сделать самый банальный. Плаванье то же отсутствует.
4) Отсутствие определенных настроек в игре и самом лаучере.
5) Не работают настройки управления с лаучера.
6) В описании игры заявлены русские субтитры, и тут сразу понятно что разработчикам было все равно. Даже Гугл-переводчик так халтурно текст не переводит. Одним словом маркетинговый ход. (И тут даже дело не в том, "Иди учи английский язык и сможешь играть нормально" - как большинство говорит. А в том, что работа сделана не качественно относительно обещанного в описании).

[u] Самый главный минус [/u] - Свобода передвижения по локации, напрочь убила историю которую нам рассказывают. Ты можешь ходить куда хочешь, но когда дойдешь до определенного места начнется монолог. И из-за неправильного порядка посещения мест, история получется рваной.

P.S. Брал по летней скидке в 15 рублей, но такая не качественная работа стоит червонец и то, только в уплату музыке.

review:
[b]# GRA "ORACLE" TO OBIETNICA BEZ POKRYCIA ! [/b]

1. W tej grze nie ma ładnych lokacji i nie ma dobrej grafiki! 
Zła jakość grafiki rzuca się w oczy już w pierwszych sekundach po uruchomieniu gry. To nie jest grafika sugerowana przez film rekalmowy na stronie "Steam". Lokacje w tej grze są, co najwyżej, średnie (a moim zdaniem są brzydkie!). Osobiście, przypominały mi nieużytki rolne pod rekultywację, a nie teren pięknej i tajemniczej wyspy. 
Grafika jest rozmyta i niewyraźna, kolory brzydke, część obiektów zlewa się z otoczeniem, niektóre obiekty są wręcz paskudnie czarne (dosłownie!), np. tzw. labirynt. 
Uwaga: w tej grze grafiaka wczytuje się na naszych oczach, zwłaszcza dalsze obiekty! Myślałem, że to wina mojego komputera, ale to samo można zobaczyć w filmachn na YT pokazujących przejście gry przez innych graczy!  

2. Jeśli liczysz na piękne zrzuty ekranu, co w symulatorach chodzenia jest typowe, to w tej grze jest to możliwe ale BARDZO TRUDNE ! Niech nie sugerują nas piękne screeny na Steam, zauważmy, że większość z nich to przeróbki screenóww w specjalnych programch graficznych.

3. W grze znajduje się ścieżka, która niby nas prowadzi, ale jest ona tak skonstruowana, że mamy wielką szanasę zgubić ją i błąkać się bez sensu po pustym i - moim zdaniem - brzydkim świecie gry.

4. Nasza postać porusza się bardzo powoli i koślawo. Brak możliwości biegania.

5. Gra nie działa płynnie lecz skokowo (bardzo lekkie "skoki" lecz zauważalne i wpływające na komfort rozgrywki). Znowu myślałem, że to wina mojego komputera, ale to samo widać w filmach na YT.

6. Akurat te obiekty, które budzą prawdziwe zaciekawienie gracza i, do których chcielibyśmy wejść, są niedostępne. Budzi to rozczarowanie i niedosyt.

7. Gra skończy się w momencie gdy odwiedzimy wszystkie miejsca i zdobędziemy wszystkie 24 osiagnięcia. Piszę o tym, ponieważ nie wynika to z fabuły gry i potencjalny gracz może nie wiedzięć jak zakończyć rozgrywkę.

[b]# Podsumowanie:[/b]
# Symulatory chodzenia są jednym z moich ulubionych gatunków gier. Ten produkt mogę polecić tylko najbardziej zagorzałym fanom tego gatunku, a wszystkim pozostałym NIE POLECAM ! "Oracle" to zmarnowany czas i pieniądze.

# Jeśli chcesz zagrać w fajny symulator chodzenia z pięknymi lokacjami, polecam "Drizzlepath" lub "Leaving Lyndow". Cena każdej z tych gier jest wyższa ale naprawdę jest to inwestycja lepsza niż "Oracle". 

[h1]# Moja ocena to: 3/10
# GRY NIE POLECAM ![/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198056982750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1589411630}
review:
There are several things I like in a game.

1.) Good Story:              This was not accomplished but could be. A story must have a beginning and an end and it must be understood. Unfortunately, this was not accomplished to my satisfaction and to others as well according to the reviews. That fact makes this unfortunate because there are so many simple things  that could be changed with it to improve it's satisfaction to it's target users. Most people willing to try a new game are looking for something new and the story line is key. This game is a non violent, casual , discovery and exploration without the strange puzzles, first person character, graphic rich, and an open simple world with simple rules and the story line should reflect this as well for the target audience. How many of us looking for a new game have taken the chance and been disappointed? By the reviews I would say many. Looking for killing? Look elsewhere , it's not in this game, nor should it be. This game is not about overcoming physically, it is a more a mental battle something we all fight every day.

    So what good is it to be critical if you don't suggest an improvement?        Useless.   Useful feedback is a must in anything we do.
              
              MY suggestion is that you play to the games strengths, the character died to get here and they know it! They have entered a new world based on what they have done while alive and like all people have burdens and life regrets. Many people wish for a do over in their lives but what they actually need is to make a bad decision right so they can live with it. Why not a game that meets that need? That makes the story line more believable and relatable. To like a character a relationship between player and character must be established at the very start!  So at the story start, the ending of the characters life may be world destruction or personal death it makes little difference but should be known before they start the game. Advertise it in the sales pitch. They are making a journey through their life to see where the character went either right or wrong in his decisions and they may be seeing signs of the wreckage in their life around them, but also the good and beautiful things as well.  For instance I was drawn to the church, hope is a wonderful thing. I wanted to explore it more, the graveyard, sadness so being drawn there it was not for the same reasons. I was curious. 
     Use the emotional graphics to continue to draw players in. The graphics would require little change and so would the story as it stands, just mostly the narration and the initial selling advertisement to make the story line understandable. So that it entices the player and they want to see where the story leads. You, as the character, walk through a world where you cannot be killed or hurt but as you come to understand the player character's decisions at each checkpoint your emotional burden is lessened. You get a perk perhaps in that your vison sharpens, your hearing improves or you see more clearly.  You understand more of the story and it's goals. That would account for long falls and not drowning as well. The idea is not to inflict pain on the character in this game but to remove it from the character and make the character stronger. The game should improve the character so that the game is more satisfying to the player. Everyone loves a winner. Sometimes you may have to discover a way out like walking underwater, but there always has to be an obvious way out, a trail, even if it is obvious and somewhat long or winding. The game would end after you found all the checkpoints and then in a flash, maybe multicolored, with those rainbows or Aurora's as one reviewer suggested, the world vanishes and you are ready to move on and this game ends, until a sequel? Maybe.  

2.) Simple and responsive game controls:          The controls are simple, but there is no tutorial.  You have to look in the setup before you get in the game to see what you can do.  On the whole this is not a show stopper but for those who like to just jump in it can be annoying. I like a pace in the game where you can pick your own speed through it. This game does allow casual speed or you can race through if that is your wish, I personally, would rather go slowly and explore.

3.) Graphics:           The graphics here for a first run test are very good. Are there glitches? Yes, but consider the time, effort and work put into the setup of this on a marginal budget and limited time and it is an excellent first shot. Most games are a labor of love you almost never get out of them the work you put into them. The code is not going to be perfect the first time around. Proof? Check out Skyrim, years later you might still get flying mammoths and such even with all the excellent and creative mods. Sometimes, the fixes break other things. Overall I was pleased with the first shot. As improvement for later, butterflies, birds and friendly animals would be a plus. In this type of game it's what you see that helps to sell it. Think of this game as a quiet walk in the park with some soul searching and it could be different enough and relatable enough to improve.

4.)  Miscellaneous:       The clunky, over loud, boring and constant walking sound detracts from the excellent music and the colorful surroundings. My view, take it out. Add more eye candy, more music so it does not keep playing one song over and over. Let's highlight the musicians versatility a bit. It is one of the things that add's sell value to the game. Everyone likes good mood background music in the game, new inspiring music in the game could even be one of the perks I mentioned previously. That is what every muscian wants to do, reach the audience. What if the music starts off sad and gets happier as the player moves through the checkpoints, a very nice perk. The character starts off alone later they see butterlies, rainbows, animals etc. Make the game a positive experience and build it as you go so that the ending is BETTER than the start. Every player loves to work to win the game and this gives them more reason to do so besides the concept of "let's get this over with and never come back." You want repeat business? Trust me, a loyal happy fan base is a goal you have to build into your game from the start. Size of the game does not matter, it's what the player gets out of it that counts.

   Like most here my review is mixed. What makes me recommend it is what it could be. It's a first shot but shows great promise for those of us out there who wish to try new concepts and ideas in our games. However, to show that promise, suggestions, encouragement and a little cash out lay may be required. Let's just say that I am investing in it's future, not unlike the possible game story itself. If it thrives then I made a good decision in this life if not? I lost some money to a dream but it could be worth it if the developers don't get discouraged and take the time to make the game better. I would like to hope so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171339687', 'num_games_owned': 4711, 'num_reviews': 644, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1523134852}
review:
« Simulateur de marche ». On peut mettre un tas de trucs derrière cette appellation, vraiment.
Comme son nom l’indique, ce genre n’est pas un jeu vidéo à proprement parler, mais plutôt une expérience voulant reproduire la sensation de marche dans un cadre prédéfini, jouant plus ou moins avec les lois de la physique selon le thème. Le gameplay étant réduit à presque rien, une recette de ce genre n’a de chance de fonctionner que si elle propose des éléments périphériques (musique, bruitages, graphismes, voix, contrôles) de qualité.

Pari presque réussi pour Oracle qui a l’intelligence de s’afficher en magasin pour 0,79 euros. Quelques musiques inspirées, des monologues bien placés, et un décor cohérent. On aura cependant fait le tour de la carte en une heure environ, collecté succès et cartes Steam au passage, le tout sans support manette ni traduction Française. Dommage.

Compte-tenu des bugs graphiques ici et là, ainsi que la sempiternelle histoire du mâle Beta qui recherche sa muse vaginale dans la nature, je suis mitigé. Le prix canon l’emporte cependant, et mérite notre indulgence.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979864325', 'num_games_owned': 2629, 'num_reviews': 501, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1523377943}
review:
Очень странный инди-проект, а по сути, очередной симулятор ходьбы на Unity.

К играм подобного жанра всего два требования - сюжет и графика (или хотя просто приятная визуальная составляющая). Ни первого ни второго здесь нет. А может и есть... 
Но первый пункт разбивается в пух и прах об чугунную жoпу машинного перевода, так что если вы знаете английский язык, играйте без русских субтитров. 
А второй пункт... игра хоть и пытается быть симпатичной, но эти однообразные подсолнухи, это однотипные травинки и деревья... даже два огромных и одинаковых черепа рядом друг с другом, у них даже зубов одинаковых нет. Не стали заморачиваться в общем. И эти внезапно появляющиеся вдалеке огромные деревья, с учётом специфики локации (огромные просторные поляны и лесочки) - это дикий косяк.

Казалось бы, ну как можно еще испортить игру, в которой нужно всего лишь ХОДИТЬ? Осталось испортить саму ходьбу! 
Спринта как такового нет, прыжки непонятно зачем (хотя при помощи прыжков мне удалось подняться по лестнице со дна озера, в которое я упал с огромной высоты, и нырнул я в него словно в воздух и до самого дна), хождение само по себе унылое и скучное, а еще можно бесконечно ходить под водой словно пират из "Пираты Карибского моря"... окей, утонуть нельзя, так дайте хоть с горы сброситься, в общем, хоть как-то покончить с этой игрой... но даже если вы шмякнетесь об землю с огромной высоты - не произойдёт абсолютно ничего. 

Ну и небо... небо можно было бы и покрасивее нарисовать, даже в играх начала 2000 умели сделать красивейшие анимированные облака и тучки. 

Что мне понравилось, так это лишь ключевые локации, вернее их постановка. Ну просто интересные, каждая из них - просто жемчужинка в этом бесконечном поле отсутствия какой либо жизни. За нахождение каждой из этих ключевых точек игроку и выдают ачивки. Найди их все и получишь счастье и радость, но знаете... мне такая радость нафик не нужна, мне жаль потраченного времени.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257134966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1521779874}
review:
I bought this game for $0.50 (on 75% sale) so I didn't expect too much. The team are good world-builders - lots of pretty forest and plants, lakes and grass. The first thing I did was walk into a lake (for reasons) and still made the same slow clomping noise as when on land. Didn't drown or swim. Fair enough, moving on.

Walked along the path a bit, and got a bit of monologue that was your character (assumedly) talking about a fairly banal experience when he was interviewed. Walked around (very slowly!) to another few places and got some more monologue, but I tried to reach a castle across the bridge and a) I kept falling straight through the bridge, and b) I couldn't jump over a barrel 1/3 my size. At this point I decided to give up, since there didn't seem any point to continuing.

The world was pretty, much better than I expected from a small indie dev. Not ground-breaking, but fantastic for the price. Music was good background. However the movement speed was extremely painful, and there is no 'autorun' function so my finger got tired after 15 minutes. Kept getting snagged on trees, grass, buildings and sticks. The monologue was certainly not interesting enough to keep me dawdling about aimlessly hoping to finish the story.

Played the game for... 20 minutes? Half an hour? And then figured, "Well, if I want to walk in the bush, might as well go for a bushwalk instead of playing a slow and fairly dull computer game."

The devs are certainly on the right track and it's a decent glimpse into what they can do, but all things considered I want my half hour back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014533728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1518346466}
review:
I abandoned it after jumping into a pond to see what would happen. I could breathe underwater and walk around but I couldn’t swim or climb out. That was only about 20 minutes into it but I couldn’t handle the thought of repeating the first 20 minutes. I’d started to question everything about my life in that short time and took getting stuck as a sign to give up and return this game.

I’d seen the mixed reviews but I liked Dear Esther so I approached Oracle with an open mind. The first few steps were alright although I couldn’t help hearing the overly loud THUD THUD THUD of the footsteps. The noise didn’t change whether I walked on grass, rocks or wood. The thuds are also very slow as if you’re somehow taking giant 2 metre strides. As I looked around the distant objects appeared slowly. Big grey miscellaneous objects slowly took on a shape. Then the man  started talking and it was like Vogons had write the script. I kept wondering what he was on about but I doubt anyone knows. 

After a few minutes I’d managed to gloss over the THUD THUD THUD, bizarre dialogue and drawing distance and was starting to enjoy it. It’s an attractive island and I thought maybe I’d like exploring it for a couple of hours. Then things got strange again. I tried to walk under a bridge but was prevented by an invisible wall. I could walk around the bridge but not under it. I walked to the top of the bridge and the bridge ended. I wondered what would happen if I tried to step off. Would my character die or would it somehow stop me from falling. I’d not considered the possibility that I’d fall and carry on walking as if nothing had happened. A 20 metre drop may as well have been 20 centimetres. It was around this time I realised it was becoming less enjoyable. 

I initially liked the way you can walk almost anywhere (as long as there are no invisible walls) but I realised you could very easily miss a location. As I wandered I’d not triggered any speech for a while. It started to feel like hard work, a bit boring and the sort of thing where you’re almost glad when it ends. This was when I decided to jump in the pond. It let me jump in but I couldn’t get out. I reloaded, hoping it would have an earlier checkpoint, but I was still in the water. I walked around for a bit, the lack of oxygen not an issue, but I wasn't going to get the game finished from inside a small pond. Perhaps I could have worked out how to get out but the thought came to me that, worst case scenario, I would have to restart. There aren’t many games where the prospect of replaying 20 minutes because of a lost save is that bad but I couldn’t bring myself to do it. If you don't want to play 20 minutes again it's time to give up. 

I really wanted to like this game and I feel bad that I’m giving it a thumbs down. I didn’t like it but some people did, plus it was cheap. It just ended up too frustrating and flawed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049991149', 'num_games_owned': 3565, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1515627971}
review:
I love walking simulators.  I have a lot of them.  As a writer, I find inspiration in the visuals, but usually the writing in these games tends to be poetic, experimental, confusing and hard to follow.  This is no exception.  I wasn't really very impressed at first, there's so many floating rocks (both in water and in the air), floating grasses, trees, flowers, lots of invisible walls.  At times things would shimmer when they shouldn't be, and I walked right through most of the bodies of water, since there's no swimming.  But I changed my mind about the game eventually.  Not a creature anywhere to be seen, though they did a nice job of hiding the lack of them with audio of birds and insects.  The piano track that repeats in the background is pleasant and calm and frankly made it difficult to stay awake as I wandered aimlessly all over the place, stumbling on weird little things, everywhere, wanting so badly to get to that big building on the hill.  I realised the sun was slowly inching down behind me, so I kept the game on to watch the day end.  The nighttime was great, where the audio changes to crickets and the lighting is dim and dark.  
I got Oracle for less than $1 last year and just got around to playing it today.  It could use a lot of polish, there's no denying that, but if you feel like just wandering a while for some quiet escape time, it's really not too bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001137917', 'num_games_owned': 2099, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1514264756}
review:
Considering the fact that Oracle was developed by a team of five, with each seemingly taking on one task all by his own, I appreciate the effort that went into it. Though sadly, I must conclude that it doesn't cut it, even from a gamer's perspective who enjoys walking simulators.

You wake up by a campfire at the shores of an abandoned island as the first piece of narration kicks in. Just as in most examples of the genre, the backstory is told through the monologues of the protaganist, who, in this case, is a solitary man that chose to escape from the society and dwell on an abandoned island on his own. Glimpses of his past life, as well as his comments on various unfortunate events that took place in the said part of his days are revealed piece by piece, whenever you reach some kind of landmark throughout your lonely exploration of the titular island.

Unfortunately, that is all there is. Oracle's overall lack of progression makes it a shallow experience at best. This being a pure walking sim at its heart, the lack of environmental or character-based interaction, as well as there being no objectives other than wandering and listening to the soliloquies on offer, are tolerable. However, it looks like dropping the clueless player into an overly vast island, which in itself does not have any clear paths to follow, was a misstep. I'm sure that many a player got frustrated and felt lost in the first few minutes. The thing is, I too, would most likely not find my way around without taking hints from the achievement descriptions. Bearing in mind the fact that one can not conclude the journey unless s/he finds all the landmarks which trigger the (decently acted) narrative pieces one by one, it's easy to assume that this may very well be a test of patience for most, rather than the calming experience it strives to be. Exploration is to be taken as reward-in-itself in this genre, unless that exploration turns to a systematical scan of the game world on offer, which clashes with the basis of it all.

The problems with the audiovisual and technical side of things do not help it either. The constant pop-ins/outs of the distant objects and environmetal props, coupled with the repetitive texturing and the pixelated skybox make it hard to suspend one's disbelief. The said pops also affect the explorative aspect of the game, since what looks like a barren plain from a certain distance may actually be housing a landmark that needs to be visited. Above all else though, the greatest deterrent is the painfully slow pace of the player character: with an island of this extent, it would be wiser to let the explorer walk a little faster, or tweak the so-called 'sprint' ability so that it actually feels like sprinting rather than a momentary thrust. Adding insult to the injury, looking around does not feel smooth either, most likely due to a forced interpolation of the mouse movement, with no remedy in sight since there aren't any options to speak of apart from the standart Unity welcome-screen with the resolution and quality modifiers. The single, soothing background track does its job pretty well though. Sadly, its impact is marred by all the factors mentioned above.

All in all, Oracle fails to impress. The protaganist's hour-long wandering does not offer any kind of catharsis for him, nor a fully-realized experience for the player. If you are new to walking simulators, this shouldn't be your starter. If you're familiar with the genre however, know that Oracle is nowhere near the quality you've come to know from the cream of the crop.

review:
Pros:

- It's an Open World Dear Esther
- It reminds me of a dream I had
- Nice music
- Easy cheevos
- Mountain jump-climbing that puts Skyrim to shame with how easy and satisfying it is

Cons

- Unity and all the graphical bugs that come with it
- mish-mashed Asset Flip that makes no sense
- Story is beyond pretentious and throws a lot at you without giving you a reason to be interested
- Giant skulls, giant skulls out of place everywhere
- The invisible walls don't protect you from seeing the incredibly unfinished background in the back side of the island

It's an easy, peaceful way to spend an hour, but if you're wanting something more than some ok scenery, you'll want to look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045345200', 'num_games_owned': 1477, 'num_reviews': 554, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1513611041}
review: Walking simulator, zřetelně inspirovaný legendární Dear Esther. Možná až přespříliš inspirovaný, protože hra působí nuceně. Příběh se snaží být surrealistický, ale bohužel tím naprosto ztratil smysl. Lokality jsou pěkně navržené, ale grafika vypadá hezky jen ojediněle. Především vykreslování textur na dálku je přinejmenším otřesné. Celý pohyb po ostrově spíše než walking simulator připomínal jumping simulátor. Vyskákat se dá totiž opravdu všude, i na sebevíc strmou skálu. Občas vás zastaví neviditelná textura, a to klidně i uprostřed louky. Také mne mrzelo, že se bez problému dá projít vodou a bez jakýchkoliv efektů. Alespoň soundtrack je velmi příjemný. Voice acting taky není úplně špatný, ale často mi přišel uspěchaný. Bohužel, v konkurenci walking simulátorů, která je dnes doopravdy velká, je tenhle výtvor podprůměr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059481175', 'num_games_owned': 1906, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1511726690}
review:
As an avid fan of most "walking simulators" ala Dear Esther, Gone Home, Everybody's Gone to the Rapture, etc, I was pumped to play another that looked pretty intriguing.

I was let down.  And I didn't even have any specific hopes outside of a meaningful narrative to be told to me through a game as I explored the world they provided.

What I found was no clear message.  What is the developer trying to convey?  Is it a love-lost story?  A story of governmental control?  The slow descent of a man's life as a whole?  I spent so much time trying to understand what the story was trying to tell me that it wasn't enjoyable at all, and after completing it, I still didn't understand what I was supposed to have gained or thought about the whole time, it just felt like I legitimately wasted time wandering in some weird fantasy realm.

I'd advice passing on this, even with the low price tag.

review:
Oracle looks intriguing. The graphics look good. After starting up, however, you start to find many flaws. The Narration is voiced well, but it makes little sense. Is the person insane? Is the translation just very bad? I still have no idea what the whole story was. If the person is insane and this is intentional, fine - even interesting. But this needs to be clear one way or the other. It did keep me interested for the 2 hrs it took to complete it. That's not terrible for a game that cost less than $1.

There or both minor and major graphical glitches everywhere you look. A mining cart with a wheel floating in the air. Rocks misplaced/lost and floating in water. Nothing so obvious as floating on the surface, but at one point I looked down into a lake and there were a couple rocks floating just under the surface. The trees do not move in the wind... so to fake it, the branches just move around. I don't mean they are flexiable.. The whole piece just moves. Probably ok at a distance, but up close it looks quite poor. One of the first I noticed was objects in the distance show up on the edge of your screen, but they disappear when you look at them if they are far away. When in a valley, or at low elevation, the clouds, which are obviously high altitude clouds, run into the trees on the hill tops looking quite awful. The list could go on quite a while. 

The audio is mixed bad. There's only one piano track, and while it's nice, it plays over and over continuously. The sound of you walking is always the same. Rocks? Moss? gravel? Wooden stairs? Always the same. The ambience isn't too bad though.

Physics - I am not sure there are any aside from gravity. You can walk off a bridge 200 feet above the ground and just keep walking when you hit. You can walk off a ledge into a deep lake and you just walk along the bottom till you find a way out. If you're tryign to walk under a tressel bridge, sometimes you can walk between the supports, sometimes there is an invisible wall. 

All in all, I can't recommend it to anyone other than someone looking for a quick 100% game. With a bit of time, I feel like the devs could have made this drastically better, and for that reason I can't recommend it, even for $1.

review: I can't bring myself to give this a thumbs-down - there was a lot of heartfelt work put into this game. I got my money's worth, got some nice screenshots, got 100% achievements. But I ended up just being glad to be done with it. The story doesn't hold together: the prose doesn't even make sense most of the time, even when you exert yourself looking for some metaphor or allegory to hang it from. It's just mumbo-jumbo that sounds like it's trying to be deep and philsophical. I'm ignoring the strange Unity-related bugs, they are not why this game isn't replayable even as a walking simulator. I end up wishing someone would just rewrite all the text boxes, and tell a different story. Very pretty, very relaxing, but there's no meaning to any of it. Recommended in spite of all this because the price is right, and because I wouldn't want to discourage people from making relaxing exploration games.

review:
I don’t typically write reviews but in the case of Oracle, I was compelled.
 
Firstly, a word of warning to other Walking Simulator enthusiasts. I purchased this title based on other reviews comparing it to Dear Esther… this game is nothing like Dear Esther. The visuals and atmosphere are good, however the story just got in the way and never really engaged me. After a few paragraphs, the needlessly complex script just felt drawn out and unnecessary. 

If you are looking for a simple walk on an unfamiliar island, then Oracle is for you, however this is all you should really expect. Last word of advice, buy a mini-weight for your W key, you will need it.

review:
A neat, prettily designed short game without much action besides walking on a strange island, discovering half-ruined landmarks and reminiscing on your relationship with a sinister woman whose influence on your life has been disastrous. The deeper nature of the narrator's feelings for and about her are gradually revealed in voiceover as he stumbles upon each key location.

Although any underlying themes are never made entirely clear, the experience in total is quite absorbing and enjoyable. That said, there are some amusingly unrealistic details, like the fact that you won't be killed even if you fall down a mountain slope - you never really fall, you just keep running along the cliff - or spend hours wandering underwater without needing to come up for air (which could simply be a device to avoid complicating the plot, but it also made me think of a certain theory that I won't divulge for fear of spoilers).

Interestingly enough, the way dry ground blends into the sea bed is poetically surreal in places, with stunning colors and blooming vegetation peeking from just below the surface of the water. The various monuments are beautifully made (if creepy sometimes) and relatively easy to find and explore - except the ancient mine which, sadly, appears to be inaccessible for some reason.

This isn't a game for action enthusiasts. It is somewhat idiosyncratic, story-driven but obscure at the same time, looking more like a demo rather than a brief but complete game. However, the lovely landscapes and dreamy atmosphere are worth at least one playthrough. The puny price and the bonus of achievements and trading cards are an additional couple of reasons to give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993502256', 'num_games_owned': 2488, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1502385620}
review:
Wo bin ich? Und warum ... und über wen spricht der da?

Alles Fragen, die mich im Endeffekt garnicht mehr interessiert haben. Oracle ist ein Walking Simulator, in dem man frei rumrennen kann. Und mit frei rumrennen meine ich, es gibt keine Begrenzungen auf den Wegen, man kann die Berge hochhüpfen (Skyrim + Pferd) und man kann somit alles frei erkunden. Das klingt gut, wenn man denn wenigstens eine grobe Richtung bekommen würde. Ich habe eine halbe Stunde den letzten Punkt gesucht, denn selbst wenn man sich an die Wege hält, habe ich einiges gefunden, aber irgendwann war einfach Ende.

Die Welt sieht dabei zusammengewürfelt aus und macht aus meiner Sicht wenig Sinn. Viele Dialoge entziehen sich, meines Erachtens nach, dem Nachvollziehbarem und die Story hat auch 0 Relevanz. Das könnte mitunter an der eher schlechten Übersetzung ins deutsche liegen, denn schon bei der Sprachauswahlt steht nicht "Deutsch", sondern "deutsche". Sobald man das auswählt ändert sich am Startbildschirm übrigens nichts. Der Sprecher der Story wirkt monoton, was ein Stilmittel sein könnte, da er in Gedanken verloren zu sein scheint. Finde ich ok, soweit.

Grafisch gibt es auch einige Abstriche. Der erste Blick ist hübsch und eigentlich wirklich gut. Doch dann kommen Grafikbugs dazu, die teilweise stören. Weitsichttechnisch könnte man auch überarbeiten, dass die Gebäude oder Gegenstände einfach so aufploppen. In der Nacht (es gibt einen Tag-, Nachtwechsel, solange will man aber vermutlich garnicht spielen) sieht einiges interessanter aus, das Gras verbindet sich jedoch irgendwie mit der Umgebung und macht einen ganz komischen Effekt.

Der Ton ist in Ordnung. Ambiente stimmt und das Geklimper auf dem Klavier beruhigt. Ist aber auch nicht herausragend.

Fazit: Ich kann dieses Spiel leider nicht empfehlen. Grafisch ist es unausgereift und ich wollte nach kurzer Zeit einfach alle Orte sehen (ein Ort = ein Achievement) und das habe ich geschafft. Ich wäre dabei fast eingeschlafen und die Story habe ich bereits vollkommen vergessen. Selbst im Angebot würde ich nur zuschlagen, wenn ich alle anderen Walking Simulatoren durch habe.

review:
The game is incredibly beautiful with some really nice landscape and water effects. I would quite often stop and look at the scenery and marval at the water lapping up on the shore or the sunlight reflecting on the waves. If you go into the water it really does feel like you are under water. I overlooked the fact that you can stay underwater indefinitely. The trees and rocks and the whole look of the game is very good for such a low priced game. 
Unfortunately that's where the positives end really. 
The character moves painfully slow. I guess it prolongs the game and gives you a chance to view the scenery but it can become a little frustrating. 
The story is non-scensical and a bit pretentious. There is no story really. Just a man talking about meeting some journalist I think. I would have much preferred it if there was a decent story related to the island. At one point they mentioned giants. Why not pick up on that storyline? 
Overall I quite enjoyed just walking around and getting all the achievements. If you like walking simulators I would pick it up in the sale. I only paid 36p ($0.5) so I definitely have no quibbles paying that. I feel there was a missed opportunity with the storyline as the environment is surprisingly well done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048974498', 'num_games_owned': 2973, 'num_reviews': 812, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1499023124}
review:
A lot of people complain about "walking simulators" being too linear, but after playing this one, I gotta say...a little linearity doesn't go astray. 

   Unless you're someone who prefers a gaming experience with quite literally no goal or purpose, other than to wander aimlessly and hear broken shards of narrative whilst accruing the occasional Achievement, the level of satisfaction on offer here may be questionable. I tend to like games with a beginning, middle and an end, and Oracle...well, I guess it has a beginning. And some stuff which comes after.

   Which is not to say the game has no redeeming features. The sound design is mostly excellent - a vivid recreation of nature in all its splendour - except that the footstep sound effects, like the painfully monotonous voice-over, don't vary much, sounding the same on wooden floorboards as they do on dirt roads. The enticingly abstract piano music which plays throughout, on the other hand, is almost enough to persuade one to forgive the game's other aural shortcomings.

   The "jump" button is a true curiosity. The sound effect it creates is...er...a little immersion-breaking to say the least, and while it's sometimes necessary to use the button to access certain areas, I encountered at least two points where I was able to magically jump by increments to a preposterous height before coming back down to Earth. A glitch, I'm presuming. Nothing much to complain about, in other words, but not exactly something to praise either. 

(I might also add that jump buttons are often a tad inadvisable in games which aim to be relaxing and dream-like, as the player must struggle with the constant temptation to idiotically bunny-hop through much of the game, especially if not much of anything is happening. Doesn't exactly add to the "atmosphere", I'm afraid.)

   The graphics are also generally nice aside from bodies of water, which are regrettably prominent throughout and look more like a "green-screen" insert than an organic part of the game's world (you CAN walk on the bottom of the lake without dying, though; which is, er, "novel" to say the least)! The draw distance of the graphics also proved somewhat dubious, as geography in the distance can sometimes vanish or appear, depending on the angle you're approaching from (I'm assuming it wasn't just my laptop, which generally has no problems with demanding graphics; though Rise of the Tomb Raider admittedly did a good job of kicking its butt)! You'll also occasionally find yourself chasing landmarks which simply can't be reached, although there's no way of knowing that 'til you've wasted several minutes trying.

   Walking speed is another frequent bone of contention in walking simulators. Here there is only one walking speed, despite the fact that holding down "shift" does try to give the illusion of slowing down by halving the amount of footsteps you hear...without the actual physical speed changing one iota. And then, of course, there's the quality of the writing, the importance of which can never be underestimated when it's the only thing resembling "narrative" in an otherwise meaningless wander. Let's just say that the writing here, while perfectly serviceable, is certainly nothing to "write home about" (pun most likely intended).

   When all is said and done, the best walking simulators have a sense of focus. Even if the story only intermittently ties in with the scenery being presented, there's still a genuine sense of the player having been on a journey from which they emerge a slightly "changed" person. Sounds a tad lofty and all, but there's ultimately not much point to the narrative unless it tells an interesting story, or at the very least tells us something about "ourselves". I don't feel this game did either, but there may be some out there who feel differently.

   Only recommended to those who think that "open world" design is a good thing, even when it comes at the expense of a more substantial narrative experience (and anyone willing to hunt down all twenty-four of those Achievements is a fuckin' SAINT, I tell ya).

Verdict: 6/10.

review:
Il ne m'a coûté que 49 centimes, mais je regrette quand même. 
Le jeu avait du potentiel:
 Les graphismes sont beaux, un peu à la Skyrim. La musique n'est pas mauvaise non plus, quoique vite lassante. 

Seulement voilà: c'est un peu vide. 
 Les structures à explorer sont à des kilomètres les unes des autres. Et une fois sur place, on ne peut même pas y entrer.
 Le narrateur se met à vous raconter un épisode ou une anecdote de sa vie.. mais la ligne temporelle n'est pas claire, les tournures sont parfois alambiquées. Bref, on ne s'y retrouve toujours pas. 

Il aurait clairement fallu que les développeurs incluent la possibilité de visiter les bâtiments, pour peut-être y trouver des notes sur la vie du narrateur. Ou au moins la possibilité de ramasser des objets en lien avec "l'histoire". Parce que la seule que je "m'amuse" à collectionner jusque là, ce soit les récompenses steam...

author: {'steamid': '76561197983152533', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1545697587}
review:
I really wouldn't recommend this unless it was less than 1$ or free to play. There is so many good walking simulators in Steam, but when it comes to Oracle it feels that it is swiftly develeoped and the story + enviroment is crudely pasted together that holds just barely.

There just doesn't seem to be any immaculate element in this game - the island which is available for player to explore is filled with random landmarks and each of these reward player with storytelling which is bizarre and so clueless that it's really hard to if not impossible to keep track on it. From the very beginning to the conclusion I had no clear vision what narrator wanted to tell me, but I might have been too bored even to think about it. There is also apparent graphical glitches occasionally and the exploration is roughly limited with invisible walls.

Every cloud has a silver lining though. While the Unity has made it much easier to develeop visually impressive games there was a few points where I forgot the dullness and cons for a moment and just admired the landscapes around me while decent ambient music reached my ears..

If you have a thing with walking sims I really would look elsewhere, but if you still keep considering I am sure that the Oracle won't kill your wallet with those couple of bucks it asks.

review:
The first impressions were not great. The graphics are obviously busted and the view distance was very difficult to deal with. Since this is a walking simulator, it is among some of the worst out there. The walking speed is painfully slow which ruins the beauty of walking simulators that it was absolutely torturous being forced to walk slowly on the incredibly hideous  landscape. Sure there are some beautiful moments in this game but this game reminds me too much of the infamous broken game called Jurassic Park: Trespasser back in year 1998. Their graphics and gameplay are surprisingly similar. There are plenty of glitches and invisible walls that add to this unpleasant experience. This certainly did not help me to enjoy Oracle.

The only positive is the narration. The narration and difficulties the main character deals with are somewhat solid but that is something to be expected in all first-person adventure games though.

Overall, Oracle is simply NOT a good game.

3.2 out of 10

review: While I like walking sims, this one has a lot of the worst issues these games can have.  It looks kind of nice, which you can say about most of them.  As mentioned the draw distances are wonky and there are no graphical settings other than resolution (it didn't list my monitor's res).  The game claims dozens of locations, but there really aren't that many places to go or things to hear.  There is no path.  You basically go anywhere on the map except the castle on the hill with the invisible wall stopping you.  I didn't get more than 45 minutes and couldn't see anything I missed.  The voice acting would be nice except there are no audio controls so the voice is set way louder than the pleasant music.   Here's the thing about pleasant music and calm narrators.  It can make a junky narrative sound completely reasonable.   If any human being said these things outside of a calm voice lulling you into thinking it's poetry, you'd think the person had mental problems.  Honestly the narrator is just gushing about a woman who is most likely a complete sociopath and the narrative literally goes nowhere.    I'd say something similar about the Drivel Path games, except that at least those are much more complete, much longer, more intricate, and are on a completely different level graphically and atmospherically.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986360343', 'num_games_owned': 1568, 'num_reviews': 866, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1489587482}
review:
Oracle is perhaps a great first step towards the walking simulator genre. A good game to experience what it means to play such a casual game with a peaceful environment. 

The problem is that the game often feels unpolished. We explore interesting locales with our globe-trotter protagonist but some of these locations feel unfinished. You have clipping issues here and there, glitches occur randomly and some of the objects (including trees) seem to be floating just above the ground. 

It's nice to have high mountains and - as the description says - a 5 square mile map but what is the purpose of this if you see a lot of "empty" areas? I saw a section of a mountainous region only to notice texture issues. You can also jump into the water but swimming is not an option - you walk on the underwater floor while looking at the plants and strange effects accompanying this experience.

The music and the voice over are great. The game reminded me of Bottle several times, however, the aforementioned game was a properly finished product. And while the story is interesting it can never reach the level the Old City Leviathan has.

I do not wish to be too critical. Oracle is a somewhat mediocre walking simulator, however, some of the greater names out there can also be purchased for the same price and offer way more insight into this genre.

The story starts okay but then after what seems endless hours of wandering around in circles trying to find the next piece to the story it all gets too much so I quit.
There's no real paths to take, or hints about where to go.
The walking pace is more like a crawl and it takes forever to get between points of interest. (If ou can find them)
The graphics are fairly low end with a short draw distance which also means you can't scout from high points, as objects that may be within distance "pop in" to existance once you get close.
There is no life what so ever in the game. Its a dead island without so much as a bird flying off in the distance.
You can walk up sheer cliffs and underwater and simply using the jump button can climb any terrain but can jump a log on the ground!
After a couple of hours it just becomes a chore trying to find some hidden places to get the next paragraph of the story that by this time has already be all but forgotten.
As far as walking simulators go, this is down the bottom of the list.
Even for its low price, it is still barely worth it!

review:
Oracle is the walkingest walking simulator I have played.  The island itself is attractive enough, and buggy, and you will spend your 2 hours with the game walking around it. review:
Oracle is a somewhat decent walking simulator, there's not that much in it but it is cheap. There are some interesting sights to see, though I was disappointed to come across some invisible walls. Unfortunately, the game feels unfinished in many ways; there are no settings (at least audio levels would be nice, the dialogue is quite a bit louder than other sounds), no water sound effects, no actual fire in campfires, some plants and rocks are hovering above the ground or can be seen through, and various other nitpicks (underwater bubbles go strangely in straight lines, running is barely faster than walking)... There are also a few larger areas with nothing in them. Hopefully these will be fixed in updates.

Overall... Not terrible for a cheap walking simulator, but does feel unfinished, and there's not much depth to it. I'm being generous and still recommend if you don't have great expectations.

+ Nice little island to visit
+ Achievements

- Invisible walls
- No settings
- Overall just seems unfinished

2.5/5

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198135018057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1586546638}
review:
Первые два часа игра действительно производит приятное впечатление: можно расслабиться и прогулятся по острову в поисках локаций, раскрывающих сюжет, посмотреть на приятные пейзажи, послушать приятную музыку. 
Однако дальше возникают проблемы, которые снижают общее впечатление от игры. 
Во-первых, - для относительно большой локации - в игре нет ни карты, ни хотя бы компаса. И беготня наобум в поисках следующей контрольной точки начинает вызывать раздражение. Дневника тоже нет, так что прочитать отрывок еще раз и вспомнить, о чем шла речь в начале у Вас тоже не получится. 
Сохранение игры возможно только в контрольных точках - сюжетных локациях. Это в целом неплохо и оправдано для подобной игры, если бы не одно но: иногда персонаж застревает и не может сдвинуться с места, либо вернуться обратно, и помогает только загрузка сохранения. В моем случае персонаж застрял в предпоследней сюжетной локации - игру пришлось начинать с начала.   
В целом Oracle неплохая игра, однако в ней нет ничего выдающегося или оригинального ни в графике, ни в саундтреке, ни в сюжете - простая игра для однократного прохождения.

author: {'steamid': '76561198234554880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1488686491}
review:
The Game is a walking simlatour with an alright story and a beatiful envirnoment but a lacking atmosphere. The world doesn't feel lived it. Feels like the developer put a bunch of stuff in different places. Don't let that discourage you. From what I have played the story is interesting but lacking in context. Its like reading a good book but also starring at your screen and being forced to walk around to listen to the rest of it. 

The draw distance could be raised, especially in a game like this that isn't taxing on most hardware an "Ultra" with really great draw distance would make the game better, Also adding animals running around would be great, we hear all these birds and crickets and other animals singing about but see nothing, helps add to the envirnoment and will for sure help the atmosphere.

 (again from what i've played) There is no map, And your travel is completely based off what you see far off in the distance. While the develper has rasied the walking speed and added a a sprint the game still feels incredibly slow. But some will like that as it's quite relaxing. 

Overall a 7/10 
The technical issues aside. It's a good, relaxing game and it's just cheap enough to where i can't say i don't recommend it I'd love to what else comes from this developer as they get better at story telling and game development overall.

review:
Incomplete.

I was expecting something like Dear Esther, uncovering the mysteries of the island & the character while you're exploring scenic vistas or haunting caves. Instead there's a swathe of issues detracting from the experience, turning this into a game with the player trying to find & decipher the dialogue snippets. A few things I noticed in my brief 20 minutes of gameplay:
- The distant land is bugged. You can see trees in perfect clarity but not the land underneath them. RESOLVED(ish)
- Buildings exist but are un-enterable. 
- The path is covered in shrubs, making it easy to lose. 
- Some objects are not placed on the ground but rather hover above it. 

This needs a fair few improvements to make it worthwhile.

EDIT: Since I've been asked, I've played the latest version for another 40 minutes. Screenshots with comments can be found in the linked imgur gallery, otherwise i'll surmise here. 

This review of "Not recommended" will remain for the following reasons:
- Footfalls (steps) only have a single sound regardless of surface. This is jarring, and breaks immersion. 
- Its fairly easy to find floating objects. There is little care & attention to detail in placing objects.
- There are a number of objects that you can walk through.
- Its also not hard to find a clearly uncompletded section of the map.

Images of issues; http://imgur.com/a/CUAm2

review:
Симулятор ходьбы по острову. Остров очень большой, имеет множество интересных сооружений. Я 2 часа бродил по этому острову, все хотел найти то что начнет хоть какую то игру, но увы - больше чем ходить разработчик не предоставил. 

Графически игра выполнена очень красиво, пейзажи просто обалденные, вас будет сопровождать красивая музыка, и это к сожалению все! Хотя... в игре есть закадровый голос который рассуждает о жизни, довольно таки интересно, но если вы не знаете английского вам здесь делать не чего! В игре присутствуют русские субтитры и это пи3дeц! Перевод выполнен гугл переводчиком! Там такой бред написан, что просто советую не включать русский язык.

Пожалуй поставлю я этой игре "да", но уважаемый разработчик, будьте добры, переведите нормально игру или просто удалите поддержку русского языка!

[H1]EDIT:[/H1]
The newest update for this game addressed a few of the concerns I originally wrote in this review.  For instance, movement speed is now faster, and you can also sprint with shift.  Frame rates have improved, and the game looks a bit better off into the distance.  There is still room for improvment, but I feel that I can now recommned this game.  I also want to point out that the developer reached out to me within minutes of my review hitting the store page; addressing my concerns and discussing improvment to the game with me.  It is apparent that the developer (who is one person by the way) cares deeply for the game they created, and wants to create something that people will enjoy.  I'm confident the developer will continue to refine this game, and I'm looking forward to games released by Watercolor Studios in the future.

[H1]Original Review Below:[/H1]

I bought this game randomly seeing the low price of $1.49, and the great looking preview videos on the steam store.
While I cannot recommend this game in its current state, I can definitely see potential.  If the developer can fix a few key issues (such as the terribly slow walking speed, various graphical issues, optimization), I could recommend the game with a clear conscious.
I can pretty much sum it up my experience with a pros and cons list:

[h1]PROS[/h1]
The game looks great.  Built with unity, there are parts of the game with some really nice visuals.

Voice acting is decent. I wasn't blown away, but as far as immersion goes, the voice acting was good enough to get me interested in the story and had me looking for dialogue.

The sound track is awesome.  I truly loved it. 

The scenery gives the game an interesting twist.  There are areas and props in the game that really had me scratching my head.  Not in a bad way, but more of in a "whats going on here" kind of way.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
Right off the bat, I was hit with some really low frame-rates.  I have a beefy computer, so I'm not sure if maybe there is an optimization issue or whats going on.  It did seem to smooth out after about 5 minutes or so after I left the starting area.

Graphical issues are noticeable.  Some of the props seem to be sunken into the land (take a look at the back of the church and the windows).  The clouds do this weird thing where they can clip through the trees.  Objects seems to pop in and out as they are rendered at what appears to be a hard set render distance.  And some objects seem to render fully while others appear foggy at a distance.  I noticed this mostly with trees in the far distance being rendered seemly in the middle of the air in the distance, while the land they were on had fog of distance.  

Not always a clear direction on where to go.  After the church, I was lost.  Saw a large skull floating in the distance, so I went that way, only to wander off again.  I'm sure I missed a lot of the game from just skipping around, which is slightly annoying.  It wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the next issue:

You cannot run.  I get it, this is a walking simulator, but with the scale of the terrain in this game, it really just makes the experience feel drawn out.  Walking slowly from one place should be an experience and play a role.  Not just an excuse to make the game feel big because you move so extremely slow.  Maybe include a toggle-able option in the menu to allow sprinting for when you miss something all the way across the map.  Most people are going to get frustrated spending 20 minutes walking back and forth through an area you've already been.

Another note about moving: for some reason you can walk underwater.  When walking into water, you just casually walk under the waves as if the water was not even there.  Also, any steep terrain can be navigated by simply jumping repeatedly while moving forward.

review: Wandered around this island for 45 minutes. Found several buildings and structures, most bizarre of which was a huge skull rising into the air on the end of a sword. The reason for this being there is either beyond my comprehension or perhaps I didn't uncover everything to be found on the island, which I'm sure I didn't. Dialogue from the narrator and person living on the island pops up whenever you find a landmark. Made with Unity the graphics look pretty good and framerate ran at a steady 30. If you like a nice country stroll with soothing music in the background then try this out and perhaps you'll play the whole scenario and discover what it's all about. For currently $1.49 spend your cash and support this indie developer.
